tossups.question: This continent was home to high priests known as iracas who ruled the city of Sugamuxi. One civilization on this continent worshipped a deity known as the “Decapitator”, while another culture on this continent was governed by rulers like Nacen-Pinco from the city of Chan Chan. An archaeological site on this continent contains the Akapana Pyramid as well as the Gateway of the (*) Sun. This continent was home to a man who conquered the tribe of Chancas and reorganized his empire into the Tawantinsuyu. People on this continent created the ancient city of Tiwanaku, as well as geoglyphs such as the Nazca Lines. The most famous civilization on this continent had a capital at Cuzco and built Machu Picchu. For 10 points, name this continent home to the Inca empire.

If this thing is superneutral, then its rate of growth has no effect on consumption or labor. A work about the Philosophy of (this thing) argues that its use led to the transition to impersonal societies from communities, and was written by George Simmel. David Graeber argued in a work titled for Beads and (this thing) that this thing did not supplant an older system based on (*) trading goods. Gresham’s law states that the “bad” variety of this drives out the “good” and the rate that this thing changes holders is called its velocity. One form of this thing controlled by governments is known as the fiat type. For ten points, exchange rates govern the trade of what things, examples of which are Yen, Pesos, and dollars?

In one work by this author, God forces Jesus to create Christianity because He is jealous that other gods are not restricted to a single race. Earlier in that work by this author, the protagonist is a servant to the devil while disguised as a shepherd. In another work by this author, a woman sets off the central action by scratching the ground. In addition to (*) Joanna Carda, this author created a character that cares for an animal known as the “dog of tears” and is the only one not to suffer from the title condition. In one of his novels, the Iberian peninsula detaches from the rest of Europe. For ten points name this Portuguese author of The Gospel According to Jesus Christ, The Stone Raft, and Blindness.

In one aria from this opera, the title character tells her maid, Alisa, about how a ghost of a girl gave her advice. That aria is “Regnava nel silenzio.” This opera’s second act ends with the title character wondering who can restrain her in the sextet “Chi mi frena,” sung while reluctantly signing a marriage contract. This opera about the feud between two (*) Scottish families, the Ashtons and the Ravenswoods, ends with Edgardo stabbing himself so he can be reunited with the title character in heaven. The title character kills her husband Arturo in order to be with Edgardo during the “mad scene,” where she sings the aria “Il dolce suono.” For 10 points, name this opera based on a Walter Scott novel, by Gaetano Donizetti.

One version of this technique relies on a matrix whose creation is catalyzed by TEMED and ammonium persulfate. Zymography and a form of digestion beginning with reduction and alkylation are two procedures often used after this technique. Silver and zinc are particularly sensitive stains in this method, a variant of which uses isoelectric focusing in its second step. “Smiling” can occur in this process if excess (*) voltage is used. TAE and TBE are common buffers used in this process, which uses ethidium bromide for visualization. Ladders are used as standard markers this technique. In this technique, a comb is used to create wells in a polyacrylamide or agarose matrix. For 10 points, name this technique that separates proteins and DNA by applying an electric field.
tossups.answer: gel electrophoresis (prompt on electrophoresis; accept protein gel electrophoresis, DNA gel electrophoresis, agarose gel electrophoresis, polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis, SDS-PAGE, 2D SDS-PAGE, 2D gel electrophoresis) <Hao>
tossups.metadata: prompt on electrophoresis; accept protein gel electrophoresis, DNA gel electrophoresis, agarose gel electrophoresis, polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis, SDS-PAGE, 2D SDS-PAGE, 2D gel electrophoresis

tossups.question: After succeeding to the throne, this ruler appointed the Comte de Maurepas as an advisor. Another advisor to this man pushed deregulation of the grain market, causing his country’s peasants to revolt in the Flour War. This man allowed non-Catholics to practice their religions by signing the Edict of Versailles. After recognizing this man from a 50-livre note, Jean-Baptiste Drouet foiled an attempt by him to (*) escape to Austria. As a result of his policies, this man was forced to convoke the Assembly of Notables and the Estates General for the first time in over 100 years. This man’s finance ministers included Jacques Turgot and Jacques Necker, and he was proclaimed “King of the French” after being arrested at Varennes. For 10 points, name this husband of Marie Antoinette who was beheaded during the French Revolution.

In Egyptian mythology, one of these creatures named Rem fertilizes the land with their tears while in Chinese mythology the Peng bird turns into one of these creatures named Kun. In the Mahabharata, Dushyanta loses a ring that is later found inside one of these creatures and in Japan one of these animals is said to cause earthquakes and is named (*) Namazu. While fleeing from the Aesir, Loki turns into one of these animals but is pulled out of his hiding place when a net is weighed down. In a shooting contest, Arjuna said he could only see the eye of this animal, and Matsya is an avatar of Vishnu that takes this form. For ten points, name these animals, which when paired with bread were used to feed large crowds by Jesus, and that you might find living in rivers and lakes.

The speaker of this poem postulates, “A Hair, perhaps, divides the False and True,” before asking, “Could you but find it--to the Treasure-house” in the same verse. This poem contains a section where the speaker speculates, “never blows so red the rose as where some buried Caesar bled.” This poem states that humans are, “no other than a moving row/of (*) magic shadow-shapes that come and go.” The first verse of this poem implores the reader to wake, while another verse of this poem begins with the lines,“The Moving Finger writes; and having writ, / Moves on.” The speaker of this poem famously asks for, “A Jug of Wine, a Loaf of Bread, and Thou” in one of its many quatrains. For 10 points, identify this Persian poem famously translated by Edward Fitzgerald and written by Omar Khayyam.

Hydrogen is represented as a circle with a dot and helium as a circle with a line in a weird notation created by this man. This man discovered that adding certain salts to water did not increase his volume, and he also independently rediscovered the Hadley cell. This man included a definition of the dew point along with the observation that rain occurs when temperature decreases in his (*) Meteorological Observations. This scientist thought that discoloration of the liquid in his eye led to his colorblindness, and he proposed an incorrect “law of greatest simplicity.” This scientist postulated that atoms combine in whole-number ratios to form compounds, and he also found that the total pressure of a mixture of gases is equal to the sum of its partial pressures. For 10 points, name this English chemist who names a law of “multiple proportions” and also pioneered the atomic theory.

One piece in this key is the only symphonic work by Paul Dukas. Both of George Bizet’s symphonies are in this key, and this is the key of Beethoven’s first 28 Diabelli Variations. One piece in this key includes a F major second movement marked Introduzione: allegro molto; that piece is Beethoven’s (*) Waldstein sonata. Schubert’s final symphony is in this key, while another work in this key ends with a double fugue that grows into a five-voice fugato. Johann Peter Salomon coined the name of one work in this key, the Jupiter Symphony. A famous piece in this key features a recurring theme played over a constant snare drum ostinato. Bolero is in, for 10 points, which key with no sharps and no flats?

After studying under the swordsman Clery in France, this man developed the M1913 cavalry saber, which is often named for him. This man replaced Lloyd Fredendall as commander of the II Corps in World War II after the Battle of the Kasserine Pass. As commander of the Third Army, he led the siege of (*) Casablanca as part of Operation Torch and defended Bastogne during the Battle of the Bulge. On D-Day, this man’s army carried out Operation Fortitude, which tricked German soldiers into thinking the Allies were invading Calais. This man was relieved of his command for almost a year after slapping two shell-shocked soldiers during the Sicily Campaign. For 10 points, name this American general known as “Old Blood and Guts”.

This artist showed two men and a couple staring at a bright object in the night sky in two paintings of people “Contemplating the Moon”. Several monks walk toward a ruined Gothic church surrounded by twisted trees in this man’s The Abbey in the Oakwood. This artist controversially placed a religious shrine on a mountain in his Cross in the Mountains, also known as the (*) Tetschen Altarpiece. Five people stand at different distances from a shore while five ships sail on a sea in this man’s The Stages of Life; he also depicted the shipwreck of the HMS Griper in The Sea of Ice. This artist’s most famous work shows a man with a green coat and walking stick standing on a precipice. For 10 points, name this German artist of Wanderer above the Sea of Fog.

In 2015, India’s Supreme Court banned and then reinstated a Jainist form of this action which occurs when the believer has no responsibilities, called Sallekhana or Santhara. Jews perform this action on Tisha B’Av, the saddest day of the Jewish calendar, to remember the destruction of the First and Second Temples. Hindu women perform this action to bring blessings for their husbands (*) during Karva Chauth. Along with abstinence, Catholics perform on this during Ash Wednesday and Good Friday and sometimes during Lent. The Islamic form of this practice takes place between Suhoor and Iftar and is broken by Eid, called Sawm. For 10 points, name this practice which Muslims undertake during the daytime throughout Ramadan.
tossups.answer: fasting [description acceptable, accept suicide or similar descriptions before “Tisha B’Av”] <Mathew>
tossups.answer_formatted: fasting <Mathew> [description acceptable, accept suicide or similar descriptions before “Tisha B’Av”]

tossups.question: A formula named after this man can be expressed in 2 parts as g equals f star 1 and f equals mu star g, where “star” is the Dirichlet convolution. Applying that namesake formula repeatedly on the totient function will yield the identity function, then the sum-of-divisors function. A set of transformations named after this man form the projective linear group PGL(2,C) and are defined as a plus z b all over the quantity c plus z d for complex z. This man’s inversion formula uses his namesake function, which returns 0 if n is not (*) square-free and 1 if n is square-free with an even number of prime factors. The real projective plane can be constructed by gluing a disk to an object named after this man, and the Euler characteristic of that object is zero. Two of those non-orientable surfaces named after this man can be glued to create a Klein bottle. For 10 points, name this German mathematician, whose namesake one-sided “strip” can be made by twisting a strip of paper and gluing the ends.

This author asserts that there is, “Not a whisper, not a thought / Not a kiss nor look be lost,” in a poem that tells its subject to, “Lay your sleeping head, my love / Human on my faithless arm.” In another work by this poet of “Lullaby,” the speaker calls a dead man, “my moon, my midnight, my talk, my song,” before referring to him as “my North, my South, my East and West.” That poem begins with a command to (*) “Stop all the clocks, cut off the telephone.” Another poem by this author proclaims “We must love one another or die”; that poem is set in a “dive” on Fifty-second street, and is about the outbreak of World War II. For 10 points, identify this author of “Funeral Blues” and “September 1st, 1939.”

In Marx’s Concept of Man, Eric Fromm argued that Karl Marx centered his thought on a humanist example of this philosophy. A lecture titled for this philosophy presents a thought experiment that claims that Kantian and Christian morality fail to solve the dilemma of a man who chooses whether to join the army or protect his mother. Another work in this philosophy examines Abraham’s sacrifice of Isaac and stresses the need for a (*) “leap of faith.” This philosophy “is a Humanism” according to one work and is exemplified by a play where Inez, Garcin, and Estelle are trapped in Hell, that play is No Exit. For ten points name this philosophy of Soren Kierkegaard and the author of Being and Nothingness Jean-Paul.

On his first day in office, the current president of this country formed a cabinet consisting of only white men, sparking protest from women’s rights activists. In 2017, this country’s current president was recorded discussing bribes with a jailed politician but was acquitted in a 4-3 decision by this country’s Supreme Court. The businessman Marcelo (*) Odebrecht was jailed for his role in a scandal in this country. Since 2014, Sergio Moro has led an investigation into allegations of corruption in this country as part of Operation Car Wash. Eduardo Cunha opened impeachment proceedings against this country’s president Dilma Rousseff, who was forced out of office on August 31, 2016. For 10 points, name this country currently led by Rousseff’s successor Michel Temer.

In this novel, Maria Wallis shoots an Englishman on a train. The protagonist of this novel thinks his eye has been gouged out after fighting a member of the Carabinieri. Mary marries the Conte di Minghetti after another character in this novel dies violently in a speakeasy. In this novel, Jules Peterson is found dead in the bed of the star of Daddy’s Girl. One character in this novel had an (*) incestuous relationship with her father, and she later marries a man who had a gunfight with Mr. McKisko, Tommy Barban. That character meets her husband in Dr. Franz Gregorovius’ clinic in Zurich, and she later divorces him after his descent into alcoholism. For 10 points, name this novel about an affair with Rosemary Hoyt and the deteriorating marriage of Nicole and Dick Diver, a semi-autobiography by F. Scott Fitzgerald.

During this conflict, several Europeans sought refuge in a certain city’s Flagstaff Tower. In response to this event, James Neill indiscriminately killed native people in the south of the country where it took place. After taking a city in this conflict, William Hodson shot three men dead outside what became known as the “Bloody Gate”. One of the leaders of this event had lost her kingdom due to Lord (*) Dalhousie’s Doctrine of Lapse. Colin Campbell defended one city during this conflict, which was sparked by rumors that the cartridges of Enfield rifles contained fat derived from beef and pork. Bahadur Shah II was reinstated as the last Mughal emperor during this event, after which he was exiled to Rangoon. For 10 points, name this 1857 revolt by Indian soldiers against the British East India Company.
tossups.answer: Sepoy Mutiny (accept Indian Rebellion of 1857 until “1857”) <Sivakumar>

tossups.question: A group of 8 three-by-three matrices named for Gell-Mann are used to model this interaction. One property of this interaction can be derived by noting that n sub f in the beta function for this interaction is less than 16. That property was discovered by Gross, Wilczek, and Politzer. String-like flux tubes may occur between two particles that mediate this interaction. In the equation for a screened Coulomb potential describing one version of this interaction, the product of radius and (*) pion mass occur in the exponent. That potential was originally formulated by Yukawa for the residual form of this interaction. A gauge theory with symmetry group SU(3) that describes this interaction has the properties of asymptotic freedom and color confinement. Gluons are the gauge bosons of this interaction, and their color charge is described by quantum chromodynamics. For 10 points, name this force, which is much more powerful than the weak force at short distances.

bonuses.leadin: During these conflicts, the ship Intrepid exploded, killing all 13 sailors on board. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these conflicts between the U.S. and pirates on the North African coast.
The Barbary states were nominally under the control of this empire, ruled by several sultans.
At this battle in the Second Barbary War, the USS Guerriere captained by Stephen Decatur captured the Algerian frigate Meshuda.

bonuses.leadin: This character seduces the Duke of Buckingham and steals two diamonds he gave to Anne of Austria as a spy for Cardinal Richelieu. For 10 points each:
answers: Milady de Winter (or Anne de Breuil; or Lady Clarick)
parts: Name this adversary of d’Artagnan, known for a fleur-de-lis branded on her shoulder.
Milady was once the wife of this man, who with Porthos and Aramis makes up the titular Three Musketeers.

In the sequel to The Three Musketeers, Twenty Years After, this son of Milady and Athos kills his uncle Lord de Winter in battle and executes Charles I. Near the end of the novel, Athos kills him underwater.
metadata: or Anne de Breuil; or Lady Clarick

bonuses.leadin: Francis Perrin discovered that this process naturally occurred in Oklo, Gabon around two million years ago. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this process in which energy is released by the splitting of a large nucleus.
This scientist was the first to explain the theory of nuclear fission. Notably, she never received the Nobel Prize for her work, the award was instead given to her collaborator Otto Hahn.

This formula can be used to determine the outcome of nuclear fission in an infinite medium. This formula does not contain the fast non-leakage probability and the thermal non-leakage probability, both of which occurs in a similar formula for non-infinite media.

bonuses.leadin: This exhibition was organized by Walt Kuhn, Walter Pach, and Arthur Davies. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this 1913 exhibition of modern art, the first of its kind in the U.S.
One of this artist’s paintings at the Armory Show was described as “an explosion in a shingle factory” by art critic Julian Street. His later artwork included a porcelain urinal signed “R. Mutt”.
Another work on display was this French painter’s canvas Ohannes. He is better known for a painting depicting Polyphemus and Galatea, The Cyclops.

bonuses.leadin: These people lived in the northeast of the so-called “Oasisamerica” region. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these people of the southwestern US, who built cliff dwellings in places like Mesa Verde National Park.

Unlike cliff dwellings, these multistory adobe buildings, commonly known as “great houses”, were built on flat plains. They also name the culture that succeeded the Anasazi in the Four Corners region.
The changing designs of this art form are used as historical records of Anasazi culture. Examples produced by the Anasazi often use the coiling-and-scraping technique and white or gray clay.

bonuses.leadin: This constant describes the frequency of molecular collisions, and whether those molecules are properly oriented when they collide. For 10 points each:
answers: one over Temperature (or reciprocal of Temperature) and ln(k) (or natural logarithm of k, k=rate constant) MUST GIVE BOTH ANSWERS TO BE CORRECT <Hao>
parts: Name this constant, which is multiplied by “e to the quantity negative e sub a over r t” (say slowly) in a certain equation.
That previous equation calculates the rate constant and is named for this Swedish scientist.

An Arrhenius plot can be used to find the activation energy and pre-exponential factor by graphing these two quantities on the axes. As determined by the Arrhenius equation, these two quantities have a linear relationship.
answers_formatted: one over Temperature and ln(k) (or natural logarithm of k, k=rate constant) MUST GIVE BOTH ANSWERS TO BE CORRECT <Hao>
acceptable: one over Temperature and ln(k) (or natural logarithm of k, k=rate constant) MUST GIVE BOTH ANSWERS TO BE CORRECT <Hao>
one over Temperature and ln(k) (or natural logarithm of k, k=rate constant) MUST GIVE BOTH ANSWERS TO BE CORRECT <Hao>

bonuses.leadin: One work by this man includes sections like “Let the Woodcutter Awaken” and “A Lamp on Earth.” For 10 points each:
answers: Pablo Neruda (or Ricardo Eliecer Neftali Reyes Basoalto)
parts: Name this Chilean poet of Twenty Love Poems and a Song of Despair.
This poem in Neruda’s Canto General asks its addressees “Rise to be born with me” and was inspired by a visit to Peru.
Conger chowder, tomatoes, and a chestnut on the ground are among the foods praised in this three-book Neruda collection.
metadata: or Ricardo Eliecer Neftali Reyes Basoalto

bonuses.leadin: Answer some questions inspired by a certain ball game. For 10 points each:
answers: Lords of Xibalba or One Death and Seven Death
Mayan Hero Twins or Hunahpu and Xbalanque
parts: After winning several ball games and sending their opponents to various houses for punishment, these gods finally lost a game and presumably killed their opponents in an oven. In reality, those opponents did not die and eventually tricked and killed these gods of the underworld.
Those opponents were these two figures often portrayed as a pair, such as day and night or sun and moon. They also defeated Seven Macaw.

The hero twins tricked the Lords of Xibalba to their deaths by offering to perform this miracle on them, which they used to survive the oven. They also used this action on a dog and Hunahpu used it on Xbalanque.
answers_formatted: Lords of Xibalba or One Death and Seven Death
Mayan Hero Twins or Hunahpu and Xbalanque
acceptable: Lords of Xibalba or One Death and Seven Death
Lords of Xibalba or One Death and Seven Death
Mayan Hero Twins or Hunahpu and Xbalanque
Mayan Hero Twins or Hunahpu and Xbalanque

bonuses.leadin: Extra copies of this structure may result in Klinefelter's syndrome, and hemophilia is a recessive trait on this chromosome. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this human sex chromosome, which most females have two copies of.
Lyonization of X chromosomes can inactivate them and form these structures. These structures are responsible for the fur color of calico cats.
This RNA gene on the long arm of the X chromosome plays a major role in inactivating it. It forms the X chromosome inactivation center along with Jpx, Ftx, Tsx, and Cnbp2.

bonuses.leadin: For ten points each, name the following related to a certain percussion instrument.
answers: Shostakovich Symphony No. 5 in D minor <Mathew>
parts: This upright keyboard instrument that sounds like a glockenspiel was featured in The Voyevoda.
This composer of The Voyevoda also wrote Swan Lake.
The first movement of this piece ends with a celesta playing chromatic scales and its composer called this piece his “creative response to justified criticism.”
acceptable: Shostakovich Symphony No. 5 in D minor <Mathew>
Shostakovich Symphony No. 5 in D minor <Mathew>

bonuses.leadin: This city was the site of the Nika Riots and the center of the iconoclast controversy. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this city, which fell to the Ottoman Empire in 1453.
In 1203, the Fourth Crusade sacked Constantinople under the leadership of Boniface I and this blind doge of Venice.
The overthrow of Maria of Antioch by Andronikos I Komnenos catalyzed this 1182 massacre of Roman Catholics by the Eastern Orthodox population of Constantinople.

bonuses.leadin: This author’s most famous work was followed by a sequel describing its title character “in Kensington Gardens.” For 10 points each:
answers: Peter Pan, or The Boy Who Wouldn’t Grow Up
parts: Name this guardian of the Llewelyn Davies boys, the author of The Little White Bird and The Admirable Crichton.
Barrie is most famous for this work, whose characters include Wendy Darling, Captain Hook, and a group of Lost Boys.
Barrie was from this region, whose other authors include Robert Louis Stevenson.
answers_formatted: Peter Pan, or The Boy Who Wouldn’t Grow Up
acceptable: Peter Pan, or The Boy Who Wouldn’t Grow Up
Peter Pan, or The Boy Who Wouldn’t Grow Up

bonuses.leadin: These systems can be classified as visual, spectroscopic, or astrometric depending on how they are detected. For 10 points each:
answers: Eclipsing binary (do not accept nor prompt on word forms)
parts: Name these systems in which two stars orbit around a common center of mass.
In this type of binary system, both stars have orbital planes very close to our line of sight, causing one star to pass in front of the other.

This star names a class of variable eclipsing binaries composed of a main sequence star and a cooler and less massive companion. Located in the constellation Perseus, it is known as the “Demon Star” for its variability.
metadata: do not accept nor prompt on word forms

bonuses.leadin: One Christian myth states that Pope Cornelius turned soldiers pursuing him to these objects. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this French Neolithic monument that is divided into Kermario, Kerlescan, and Ménec alignments.
The Carnac Stones are located in this French province, where Nantes is the largest city. This province is located to the southwest of Normandy and is home to a sizable population of Celts.
The A344 and A303 roads pass near this other megalithic monument in Wiltshire, England.

bonuses.leadin: This thinker was kicked out of the Dutch Jewish community when he was accused of pantheism. For 10 points each:
answers: Guide for the Perplexed (or Guide to the Perplexed) <McLain>
parts: Name this thinker who advocated for freedom of speech because it made people less likely to rebel. He also wrote a “geometrically ordered” book titled Ethics.

Unlike Spinoza, this thinker did not get kicked out of the Jewish community. More importantly, he claimed the God could only be described in negatives. He also codified Jewish laws in his Mishneh Torah.
This most important work by Maimonides was written as a three part letter to his student, Joseph Ben Judah. Leo Strauss claimed that this work was written confusingly to dissuade unqualified readers.

bonuses.leadin: Answer some questions about non-European campaigns in World War II. For 10 points each:
answers: New Guinea (do not accept “Papua New Guinea”)
parts: This man was defeated by Bernard Montgomery at the First Battle of El Alamein. Known as the “Desert Fox”, he commanded the German forces in North Africa during the war.
This Pacific island was the site of the Kokoda Track campaign. Japanese attempts to land on this island led to the Battle of the Coral Sea.
In one of the final campaigns of the Pacific Theater, this modern-day country was liberated from Japanese occupation after U.S. victories at Leyte, Mindoro, and Luzon.

bonuses.leadin: This author wrote about Pecola Breedlove’s desire for the titular feature in The Bluest Eye. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this American author who depicted the slave Sethe in Beloved.
The suicide of the insurance agent Robert Smith begins this Morrison novel, which centers on the life of Milkman Dead.
Published in 2015, this most recent work by Morrison focuses on the black woman Lula Ann Bridewell and her white mother Sweetness, who punishes her for her skin color.

bonuses.leadin: There are some strange crime films out there. For 10 points each:
parts: This american black comedy neo-noir film won the Palme d’Or in the 1994 Cannes Film Festival. It focuses on two hitmen, Jules Winnfield and Vincent Vega, who are played by Samuel L. Jackson and John Travolta.
This person directed Pulp Fiction, as well as Kill Bill: Volume 1 &2, Django Unchained, , and Inglorious Basterds. This person is also slated to direct the upcoming Star Trek film in 2019.
This other Tarantino film tells the tale of the murders committed by stunt driver Mike McKay using his car, which, thanks to its roll cage, give the driver this title quality.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, name the following about Jewish holidays.
answers: Sukkot [or the Feast of Tabernacles, prompt on the Feast of Booths]
parts: This harvest festival is immediately followed by Shemini Atzeret, and observers of this holiday live in temporary booths.
The Megillah is read on this holiday, which celebrates when Persian Jews were spared from Haman.
One tradition on Purim is to perform this action until Haman and Mordecai’s names are indistinguishable.
answers_formatted: Sukkot [or the Feast of Tabernacles, prompt on the Feast of Booths]
acceptable: Feast of Tabernacles, prompt on the Feast of Booths

bonuses.leadin: In a popular 2011 Youtube video, a duck infuriates a man repeatedly. For 10 points each:
parts: The duck angers the man by repeatedly asking this question, eventually leading to them taking a trip to the store.
The man does not, nor has he ever had grapes, because he is attempting to do this throughout the video.
In a highly uncharacteristic move, the duck once asks the man if he possesses this material, since the man had earlier threatened the duck with this material and a tree.
